bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 12, 1942

div1.p: Truby describes his meeting with Hench in Washington and his visit with Laura Wood Roper in Philadelphia. He mentions having heard favorable news from Harper's about possible publication of his manuscript and conveys news about his family.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 12, 1942
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Aug. 12/42
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I have been back in S.F. for a
week and am just catching up on
loose ends and things that had to be
done. What a grand trip of 3 months &
had! It was marvelous! It was so
nice to see so many old friends and
to accomplish so much. Of course
getting an appointment for Jack and
then taking him to New York and putting
him and the other boys (including your grandson)
on the Wechaushen Ferry on July 1, was the
big achievement.

Your letter of Aug 9, with the
Introduction came yesterday and I
can't tell you how much I like it.
The past about Dr. Hench pleased me
very much and I agree with you
that your statements bring out just
what happened and that they will add
very greatly to value of my story.

I did not fully understand Dr. H.
until I met him in Washington and
had a short but most interesting
AC
T
2
visit with him. I learned about
him and I feel sure he looked me
over thoroughly. He had a right to
do that, for I had flooded him with
so many things in our correspondence
that were contrary to what he had heard
elsewhere that it was only natural
that he should want to see if I had
both feet on the ground. I am anxious
to have him come out here sometime
where I can have a good long
visit with him. I also had a
very good visit in July with Laura Wood in
her apartment in Rittenhouse Square
in Phila. Before I left she said
she would have to modify some of here
statements in her book which conflicted
with my views. So she believes in
me too and that was pleasing. You
had the advantage over me in
knowing them both before you began
to give them information, so they know
from the start that you were giving
them real, trustworthy information.

But to go back to the Introduction. You
have brought out the very things I
felt were necessary and done it in
3
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
such a splendid way, that I am most
grateful. There is nothing I can
add and certainly nothing I want
to delete. I will send you a typed
copy soon. Many thanks.

I am glad you have seen Siler and
that he showed you the correspondence
re the nomenclature re. mosquitoes. In
time I will have a chance to make the
necessary conditions. Siler turned
the Mrs. over to Col. Rogers, but I have
not heard from the latter. In the meantime
I have a letter from Harper's, who have
taken over Paul B. Hoeber's publications,
stating that “We like your manuscript
very much and we hope it will be possible
for us to make you an offer of publication”
They want to know how many copies the
S.G. would buy for the army. I have told
them that the S.G. has the revised copy (they
have an uncorrected carbon which has been
with F.F. Russell and Mahlon Ashford since
it was finished (Dec. 7,41) and that I will advise
them in due time. When I hear from Rogers
I think it will be time enough to tell them.

AC
T
I have not forgotten your request
to send you a snap shot of Barbara
& her baby. I am inclosing a group
taken at the La Gorde's home on June 29,
at the time the baby was christened.

The “plebes” are at Pine Camp and from
newspaper reports they are getting a very
real workout. We have had but few
letters from Jack for he has little time
to write. He is deeply interested and
is enjoying the military work. He says
that he gets awfully tired but that he
can take it. He sees but few of his
friends as they have but few contacts
with any boys except those of their own
Company. He is in the 6th Company.

It is windy, foggy and cold out
here. August is our most month
in that respect but after all it is better
than Washington at this time of year.

I thoroughly enjoyed my visits with
you & Cornelia and Mrs Truby joins
me in love to you both.
